Fig. 3 Fig. 4 (A) FTIR-KBr and (B) area of peak 968 and 1074 cm−1 for different promoters loaded on Ni/CHE-SM. Fig. 4 Fig. 5 H2-TPR signal of (a) Ni-Ce/CHE-SM, (b) Ni-La/CHE-SM, (c) Ni-Mo/CHE-SM, and (d) Ni-Zr/CHE-SM. Fig. 5 Fig. 6 CO2-TPD results of different promoters loaded on Ni/CHE-SM. Fig. 6 Fig. 7 (A) CO2 conversion (dashed line is the equilibrium conversion), (B) CH4 yield, rate of CH4 formation, and (D) Arrhenius plot of activation energy for different promoters loading on Ni/CHE-SM. Reaction conditions: 1 atm, GHSV = 15,000 mL g−1 h−1, stoichiometry H2:CO2=4:1. Fig. 7 Fig. 8 TEM images of (A) Ni-Ce/CHE-SM and (B) Ni-La/CHE-SM catalysts. Fig. 9 Fig. 10 (A) Raman spectra and (B) Area for the deconvoluted peaks of Ni-Ce/CHE-SM and Ni-La/CHE-SM catalysts. Fig. 10 Fig. 11 Proposed structure of CHE-SM after incorporation of metals. Centre of Hydrogen Energy, Institute of Future Energy Johor Bahru Johor 81310 UTM Malaysia A series of promoters (Ce, La, Mo, and Zr) was introduced into the Ni/CHE-SM catalyst by using the impregnation method and tested for CO2 methanation. Among these, Ni-Ce/CHE-SM possessed a high CO2 conversion of 80 % at 250 °C, signifying its potential at low temperature. The superior performance of Ni-Ce/CHE-SM was attributed to the formation of Si-O-Ni and Si-O-Ce species, as confirmed by FTIR-KBr analysis. XPS and CO2-TPD analyses revealed an abundance of oxygen vacancies existed within Ni-Ce/CHE-SM, resulting in enhancement of basicity amount and strength. In addition, Raman analysis showed the existence of three and four silica member rings which was believed that the Si atom be substituted with the Ce atom, thus contributing to create more oxygen vacancies. Hence, additional active sites were provided which enhance the adsorption of reactant molecules and improve the production of CH4, thus emphasizing the greater potential of Ni-Ce/CHE-SM in CO2 methanation application. Graphical Abstract Keywords Isomorphous substitution Cerium Basicity CO2 methanation Oxygen vacancy Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction The perseverance to address climate change has intensified the pursuit of innovative strategies to reduce carbon dioxide (CO2) emissions and convert this abundant greenhouse gas into valuable products. CO2 methanation appears as one of the promising solutions in which the captured CO2 will be reacted with H2 that was harnessed through water electrolysis to produce methane (CH4) [1,2]. This process also known as the Sabatier reaction activates at temperatures ranging from 250 to 400 °C and has acquired significant interest for its potential to produce sustainable fuels [3]. However, advancements in catalytic systems for CO2 methanation are still needed to achieve high efficiency of CH4 production as well as mitigate CO2 emissions. Previous literature suggests that Ni-based catalysts are widely utilized for CO2 methanation owing to its profusion and affordability [4]. Conversely, coke formation and metal sintering were reported to occur at high temperatures for these Ni-based catalysts [5]. Hence, various strategies have been proposed to address this issue such as modification of supports, catalyst preparation, and addition of promoters [4,6,7]. For the latter case, several studies have reported that promoters such as cerium, lanthanum, zirconium, cobalt, molybdenum, and iron have enhanced the catalytic performance of CO2 methanation [8–10]. For instance, Quindimil et al. observed that the addition of La promoter provides high dispersion towards NiO particles and improves CO2 adsorption capacity towards zeolite support, thus enhancing the catalytic performance [11]. In another study, Battumur et al. reported that doping Ni/Al-15Y with 2 wt% Ce has boosted the CO2 conversion to 92.5 % at temperatures < 350 °C due to the synergistic effect of Ni-Ce interaction [12]. The addition of Ce also has been regarded as a potential promoter due to its great redox properties that can form oxygen vacancies and thus promote catalytic activity [13,14]. This oxygen vacancy can interact with an oxygen atom present in the CO2 reactant molecule, acting as an additional active site for the catalyst system. Throughout the reaction, the oxygen vacancy is dynamically created and destroyed as it adsorbs the reactant and releases product. This phenomenon is corroborating with the findings by Wang et al. for stability promoted Ni/ZrO2 catalyst applied towards dry reforming of methane at low-temperature region [15]. They reported that the C atom from decomposition of CH4 would reacts with nearby lattice oxygen, further forming CO and oxygen vacancy, resulting in enhancement of CO2 activation. This process also further enhances the ability to resist coke formation and metal sintering due to the existence of mobile oxygen species that activate carbon gasification and forming oxygen vacancies [16]. Interestingly, oxygen vacancy has been interpreted as a defect that can be found on reducible oxides which play a substantial role in CO2 methanation reaction [17]. For instance, Unwiset et al. reported that the insertion of Ni metal in TiO2 structure improves the formation of oxygen vacancies which facilitates the adsorption of CO2 species, resulting in catalytic performance enhancement [18]. On the other hand, the oxide supports with rich oxygen vacancy was found to strengthen metal-support interaction and create abundance amount of medium basic sites that accelerates the activation of CO2 and formation of CH4 as reported in a previous study [19,20]. Therefore, an efficient approach to increase the amount of oxygen vacancies in the catalytic system is needed. Foreign ion doping is one of the effective methods to amplify the quantity of oxygen vacancies in the metal oxide support along with enhancing metal-support interfacial sites [20]. This is because larger ions (e.g rare earth metal and transition metal) will be isomorphously substituted within the support framework resulting in abundant oxygen vacancies that serve as active sites. Hence, this study focuses on the addition of several promoters (Ce, La, Mo, and Zr) into Ni/CHE-SM via the impregnation method to elucidate the changes in physicochemical properties and catalytic performance. The fibrous silica MSN (CHE-SM) support was used as it enhances the dispersion of metal through the lamellar structure of the spherical fibrous silica morphology [21]. In addition, the CHE-SM support also has proved its ability in resisting coke formation and metal sintering due to the presence of unique fibrous morphology that could enhance the adsorption-desorption cycle of reactants. Besides, 20 wt% Ni loading has been used in this study as it was the optimum loading found in our previous studies [22]. All the promoted catalysts have been thoroughly investigated using a range of characterization analysis followed by their assessment of catalytic performance for CO2 methanation reaction. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation The CHE-SM support was synthesized using the microemulsion method as reported in our previous study [21]. Upon obtaining the CHE-SM, a series of promoters (cerium, lanthanum, molybdenum, and zirconium) and nickel were loaded onto the support via the one-pot impregnation method. Cerium(III) nitrate hexahydrate (Sigma-Aldrich), lanthanum(III) nitrate hexahydrate (Merck), molybdenum(VI) oxide (Sigma-Aldrich), zirconium(IV) oxide (Sigma-Aldrich), and nickel(II) nitrate hexahydrate (Sigma-Aldrich) were used as metal precursors. Example preparation procedures for Ni-Ce/CHE-SM were as follows: 0.725 g of cerium(III) nitrate hexahydrate and 0.525 g of nickel(II) nitrate hexahydrate were added into two different beakers containing distilled water. Following that, both solutions were mixed simultaneously with 1 g of pristine CHE-SM and distilled water. The solution was stirred at 80 °C until it became dried. The sample was further dried at 120 °C in the oven for 12 h and calcined for 3 h at 550 °C. For other metals loading, the steps were similar to preparing Ni-Ce/CHE-SM using the corresponding metal precursor. The amount of Ni and promoters was fixed at 20 % and 5 %, respectively, for all catalysts used in the present work. 2.2 Catalyst characterization X-ray diffraction analysis was employed to investigate the crystallinity of samples via Bruker Advance D8 diffractometer equipped with Cu Ka radiation (λ = 0.154 nm, V = 40 kV, I = 40 m A). To elucidate the surface area and pore size distribution of the prepared samples, the Brunauer-Emmet-Teller (BET) and non-local density functional theory (NLDFT) techniques were used with the assistance of Beckman Coulter SA3100 equipment. The samples were subjected to 1-h treatment under helium flow at 300 °C and subsequently nitrogen gas was passed for the adsorption-desorption process. Field emission scanning electron microscopy (FESEM) (JEOL JSM-6701 F) and transmission electron spectroscopy (TEM) (Phillips EM420, USA) analyses were carried out to illustrate the morphology of the samples. In addition, the functional groups of the sample were investigated using the FTIR-KBr technique on the Agilent Cary 640. The FTIR spectra was collected at 5 cm−1 resolutions with the range of 1600–400 cm−1. Furthermore, the metal reducibility and basicity of the prepared samples were assessed by hydrogen temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) and CO2 temperature-programmed desorption (CO2-TPD) analyses on Micromeritics Chemisorb 2720 Pulse Chemisorption. The structural information of the samples was further analyzed using Renishaw Raman spectroscopy equipment. The Raman spectra were collected in the range of 100–1800 cm−1 with a wavelength of 512 nm. The chemical oxidation state of the prepared samples was uncovered by utilizing X-ray diffraction spectroscopy (XPS) analysis (Shimadzu Axis Ultra DLD spectrometer). 2.3 Catalytic testing CO2 methanation reaction was performed in a fixed-bed quartz reactor at 150–500 °C and under 1 atm. Before initiating the reaction, 0.2 g of the catalyst underwent several pretreatment steps which were air and H2 treatment at 550 °C for 30 min and 2 h, respectively. Afterwards, CO2 and H2 gases were passed into the system accompanied by nitrogen gas. The gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) of these gas mixtures was 15,000 mL gcat −1 h−1 with CO2:H2 ratio of 4. The gases used for the reaction were ascertained as >99.9 % purity which were provided by Mega Mount. The 7820 Agilent Gas Chromatograph equipped with thermal conductivity detector (TCD) was used to inspect the product composition. Meanwhile, carbon dioxide conversion, methane selectivity, and methane yield were computed using the following expressions: (1) X CO 2 = M CO 2 , in − M CO 2 , out M CO 2 , in (2) S CH 4 = M CH 4 M CH 4 + M CO (3) Y CH 4 = X CO 2 ∙ S CH 4 where XCO2 is CO2 conversion, M is the molar number of species, YCH4 is methane yield, and SCH4 is methane selectivity. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Physical and chemical properties of catalysts 3.1.1 Structural investigation The XRD patterns of the as-prepared promoters loaded on Ni/CHE-SM catalysts are illustrated in Fig. 1. All catalysts exhibited a wide peak located at 16–32°, belonging to the amorphous phase of SiO2 in the catalyst’s framework (JCPDS card No. 29–0085) [23]. In addition, the presence of the NiO phase was detected in all promoted catalysts with the peaks located at 37.2°, 43.5°, 62.7°, 74.4°, and 78.3° corresponding to (111), (200), (220), (311), and (222) planes, respectively (JCPDS card No. 44–1159) [24,25]. Furthermore, both Ce and Zr promoted catalysts show distinguish diffraction peaks attributing to CeO2 (28.8°, 46.6°, and 58.3°) and ZrO2 (28.4°, 31.5°, and 48.9°) species [24,26]. These diffraction peaks were assigned to the cerianite-like and monoclinic phases of CeO2 and ZrO2, respectively, which are in agreement with the previous studies [27,28]. However, both promoters displayed weak intensity compared to NiO species, possibly due to the low amount of promoter loading during the synthesis process. On the other hand, the diffraction peaks for La2O3 and MoO2 species did not appear on the corresponding La and Mo-promoted catalysts, inferring that the promoter nanoparticles were well scattered on the CHE-SM surface. The average NiO crystallite size for all catalysts was estimated by utilizing 2θ = 43.5° and displayed in Table 1 by employing the Scherrer equation. The smallest NiO crystallite size was found to be Ni-Ce/CHE-SM catalyst with value of 2.49 nm. Furthermore, the average NiO crystallite size for 20Ni/CHE-SM was found to be 4.37 nm, indicating the significant interaction between Ni and Ce which improves the NiO dispersion. The assessment of Ni dispersion was evaluated from XRD via the equation below with the assumption that the Ni particle is sphere (Eqs. (4) and (5)) [29]: (4) D Ni = n s n = 4 π × R 2 × a m 4 π 3 × R 3 × p 0 M × N A (5) R = D 2 where ns denote the quantity of Ni atoms on the sphere surface; n denote the total quantity of Ni atoms in the sphere; d denote the average width of Ni particles attained from XRD; am denote the quantity of surface Ni atoms per unit area, which is 1.540 × 1019 m−2 calculated for face centered cubic (fcc) Ni using the magnitudes of low index planes fcc (1 1 1): (1 0 0): (1 1 0) = 1: 1: 1; ρ0 denote the density of Ni, 8.902 × 106 g/m3; NA denote the Avogadro constant with a value of 6.02 × 1023 mol−1; M denote the atomic weight of Ni, 58.6934 g/mol [29–31]. The results show 40.6 % Ni dispersion was achieved after addition of Ce promoter, further proving the synergistic effect between Ni and Ce compared to the other promoters. Similar studies also reported that the addition of second metal on the catalytic system has enhanced the dispersion which arise from the interaction of Ni and the second metals [32,33]. This enhancement of Ni and Ce interaction also could prevent the carbon deposition and catalyst deactivation during the reaction as the electronic and chemical properties has been altered via the interaction [34]. 3.1.2 Textural properties of catalysts Nitrogen physisorption isotherms for all promoted catalysts revealed a type IV shape, suggesting the existence of mesoporous characteristics, as illustrated in Fig. 2A [35]. Meanwhile, the hysteresis loop was ascribed to the H4 pattern that related to the slit-shape pore structure [36]. This finding is consistent with our previous report where the synthesized CHE-SM exhibited type IV isotherm and H4 hysteresis loop [21]. This phenomenon indicates that the addition of promoters into Ni/CHE-SM did not disturbs the isotherms and hysteresis loops of parent’s catalyst which could be attributed to the scanty amount of promoters. The surface area for all promoted catalysts was listed in Table 1 along with their pore volume and average pore size. Ni-Ce/CHE-SM catalyst possessed a superior surface area (260 m2 g−1) among all promoted catalysts. This is due to the excellent dispersion of this catalyst as shown in XRD analysis (Fig. 1) where the Ni crystallite size for Ni-Ce/CHE-SM is the smallest. However, the total pore volume was found to follow a different trend where Ni-La/FMSN obtained the greatest amount with the value of 0.497 cm3 g−1. This occurrence could be associated with the development of larger pores, or no blockage of the pores upon incorporation of La promoter. On the other hand, the pore size distribution of all catalysts (Fig. 2B and Table 1) confirmed the presence of mesopore (2–50 nm), aligning with the type IV isotherms. For the comparison, the textural properties of CHE-SM and 20Ni/CHE-SM were presented in Table 1. Upon the addition of promoters, the surface area and total pore volume were reduced which suggests the occurrence of pore blockage or isomorphous substitution of Si with larger ions. This phenomenon was also observed by Jusoh et al. as they found that the amount of textural properties was decreased upon the addition of Zn into MSN [37]. However, the amount of pore size distribution for Ni-Ce/CHE-SM is the least compared to other catalysts, suggesting the rapid occurrence of isomorphous substitution of Si with Ce ions. 3.1.3 Morphological investigation The morphology of all promoted catalysts is investigated using FESEM analysis and the images are illustrated in Fig. 3. It is evident that the spherical shape of CHE-SM is still preserved upon incorporation of NiO and promoters and particle size distribution was observed at a range of 600–700 nm for all catalysts. However, the Ni-Mo/CHE-SM displayed a large conglomerate which could be a combination of SiO2, NiO, and MoO3 particles as proved by the EDX mapping in Fig. 3C. In addition, the EDX mapping of Ni-Ce/CHE-SM showed a high dispersion of NiO and CeO2 species compared to the other promoters loaded on CHE-SM. This observation aligns with the NiO crystallite size in XRD findings where Ni-Ce/CHE-SM obtained the smallest crystallite size while La and Mo-promoted catalysts possessed the highest crystallite size. 3.1.4 Chemical species analysis The information regarding the vibrational of species in catalysts could be investigated by utilizing the FTIR-KBr technique. Fig. 4A displayed the FTIR spectra of all promoted catalysts in the region of 400–1800 cm−1. Conventional absorbance bands of silica species were detected in the framework of all catalysts which are located at 466, 798, 968, and a broad peak of 1074 cm−1. These four bands were assigned to the siloxane (Si-O-Si) bending, symmetric Si-O-Si, external silanol (Si-OH) group, and asymmetric Si-O-Si vibrations (internal and external vibration), respectively [38,39]. Meanwhile, the 1629 cm−1 band was consistent to adsorbed H2O retained by the silica species [40,41]. Preliminary reports stated that the intensity of peaks at 968 and 1074 cm−1 indicates the extent of interaction of metals with the framework of support [42–44]. Thus, the peak area for both peaks was calculated and displayed in Fig. 4B in which Ni-Ce/CHE-SM displayed the lowest area, suggesting high interaction between metals and support via isomorphous substitution of Si with Ce ions to form Si-O-Ce species. The deconvolution on peak 968 cm−1 via Gaussian curve fitting technique was executed for further investigation regarding the metal-support interaction. As displayed in Figs. S1 and S2, two distinct peaks were observed for all catalysts which are 965 and 970 cm−1 where it could be assigned to Si-O-M and Si-OH species, respectively [45]. The Ni-Ce/CHE-SM possessed the greatest amount of Si-O-M and the lowest amount of Si-OH, suggesting that the metals (Ni and Ce) substitute the H atom from the silanol species which could increase the active sites for the methanation process. 3.1.5 Reduction of NiO The reduction behavior of NiO to Ni° in all promoted catalysts was depicted in Fig. 5 by utilizing the H2-TPR technique. Typically, the reduction of NiO could be categorized into three regions (α, β, and γ), suggesting different extent of interaction between NiO and CHE-SM support [35]. According to the literature, the α region attributed to the reduction of small amount of bulk NiO, β region indicates the weak interaction between Ni and support, while γ region implies the reduction of solid formation between Ni and support [46,47]. Overall, each catalyst demonstrated two distinct reduction peaks that covered all of the three regions of reduction. Interestingly, all the NiO species in Ce and La promoted catalysts remained in the β region, signifying the medium interaction between NiO and CHE-SM support. The NiO species in this region could be reduced prior to the reaction and being active species for CO2 methanation. Although Ni-La/CHE-SM displayed a lower reduction temperature, the integration of these deconvoluted peaks proved that the amount of H2 consumption for Ni-Ce/CHE-SM is the highest as shown in Table S1. This phenomenon is possibly owing to the good dispersion of Ce on CHE-SM and also a contribution from the reduction of surficial Ce4+ species as observed by Bian et al. in Ni-supported CeO2 catalyst [48]. Meanwhile, the Mo and Zr-promoted catalysts exhibited a broad peak that extended to the higher temperature with 22 % and 21 % amount of NiO reduction, respectively, representing stronger metal-support interaction caused by further stabilization of Ni and promoters in the CHE-SM framework. Lu et al. stated in their study that only a small portion of NiO species in the γ region could be reduced to metallic nickel which resulted in poor catalytic activity [10]. Thus, it can be said that the Ce and La promoters have a superior ability to enhance NiO reduction at lower temperatures with appropriate strength of metal-support interaction compared to Mo and Zr promoters. This observation agrees well with the FTIR-KBr results (Fig. 4) as both Ce and La promoters exhibited high interaction between metals and support. 3.1.6 Basicity of catalysts CO2-TPD analysis was conducted for all promoted Ni/CHE-SM catalysts to assess the basic nature of the catalysts, and the results are displayed in Fig. 6. As reported in the literature, the CO2 desorption peaks could be divided into three different basic strengths that increase with temperature [49]. The weak basic sites displayed peaks below 350 °C that were associated with surface OH-. Meanwhile, the medium and strong basic sites typically illustrated distinguish peaks at 350–600 °C and above 600 °C, respectively, are contributed by metal-oxygen pairs and low coordination surface O2 -. For Ni-Ce/CHE-SM, a prominent peak centered at 489 °C was observed, suggesting the presence of medium basic sites. On the other hand, the La, Mo, and Zr promoted catalysts displayed two distinguish peaks with one of their peaks located at the strong basic sites region. Moreover, only Ni-La/CHE-SM exhibited a peak located at 350 °C that extended to the region of weak basic sites. Daroughegi et al. reported that the medium strength basicity of catalysts is more favorable towards the activation of CO2 methanation reaction [50]. Based on the areas calculated for every basicity strength of all catalysts (provided in Table S2), Ni-Mo/CHE-SM illustrated the highest CO2 adsorption capacity at the medium region followed by Ni-Ce/CHE-SM, Ni-La/CHE-SM, and Ni-Zr/CHE-SM. It could be said that Ce and Mo promoters have a high amount of metal-oxygen pairs which could probably be due to the isomorphous substitution phenomenon. However, the Ce promoter was stated to have a high tendency to produce oxygen vacancy which could extend the strength of the basicity towards the strong region as observed in Fig. 6. In addition, only La and Mo promoters have the CO2 adsorbed at weak regions due to the abundance of surface silanol as proved in deconvolution of peak 968 cm−1 of FTIR data (Fig. S1). 3.2 Catalytic performance Fig. 7 illustrates the catalytic performance of promoters loaded on Ni/CHE-SM catalysts towards CO2 methanation reaction from 150 until 500 °C. All catalysts exhibited similar CO2 conversion and CH4 selectivity behaviors as depicted in Fig. 7A and 7B. The catalytic performance is enhanced upon the addition of Ce promoter where ∼80 % CO2 conversion has been attained at 250 °C, further highlighting its potential to activate CO2 methanation at low-temperature regions (Fig. 7A). In comparison, La promoted catalysts only achieved CO2 conversion above 80 % after 300 °C while Mo and Zr promoted catalysts exhibited their potential at 400 and 500 °C, respectively. In addition, the catalytic performance of other promoted catalysts was observed to reach maximum CO2 conversion at the highest recorded temperature due to the driven force from the thermodynamics of CO2 methanation. For comparison, several recent studies that utilize the incorporation of promoters into catalytic systems were presented in Table S3. For instance, Albeladi et al. reported the catalytic performance of Zn promoted Ni silicate tube towards CO2 methanation where the catalyst achieved the highest CO2 conversion of 95 % at 400 °C [51]. Meanwhile, the addition of Ce on Ni supported graphitic carbon nitride has boosting the CO2 conversion at 275 °C with value of 85 % but further increasing the temperature resulting in decrement of catalytic performance [52]. Despite the excellent performance of other promoted catalysts, the reported Ni-Ce/CHE-SM in this study still exhibited superior catalytic performance with the highest CO2 conversion of 95 % at 350 °C. This is due to the synergistic effects among Ni, Ce, and CHE-SM have enhanced the basicity and metal-support interaction via isomorphous substitution as proved by FTIR, CO2-TPD, and H2-TPR. According to the literature, the CO2 methanation reaction is an exothermic reaction and its change of Gibbs free energy increases considerably as the temperature increases resulting in the production of unwanted products such as CO from reverse water-gas shift (RWGS) or dry reforming methanation reactions which instigate the competition in CH4 selectivity [53]. Intriguingly, all promoted catalysts demonstrated 100 % selectivity towards CH4 production as the temperature increased (Fig. 7B), thus highlighting the capability of CHE-SM support to restrain the production of unwanted products which agrees well with our previous works [21,22]. In addition, the rate of CH4 formation (Fig. 7C) at the lower-temperature region (150–350 °C) demonstrated that Ni-Ce/CHE-SM acquired the highest rate of CH4 formation. This finding further highlights the superior ability of the Ce promoter to facilitate the adsorption of CO2 and convert it into CH4 compared to the La promoter. The apparent activation energies (Ea) of all promoted catalysts were studied in the range of 200–500 °C and are illustrated in Fig. 7D. The Ni-Ce/CHE-SM demonstrated the lowest Ea value of 42.4 kJ/mol followed by Ni-La/CHE-SM (51.5 kJ/mol), Ni-Zr/CHE-SM (74.7 kJ/mol), and Ni-Mo/CHE-SM (90.2 kJ/mol). These findings further proved that the addition of Ce promoter into Ni/CHE-SM could lower the activation energy for CO2 methanation, thus improving the catalytic performance. In addition, Ea values for CeO2-based catalysts were reported to be 112.2 kJ/mol for Ni/CeO2-NR [48], 121.0 kJ/mol for Ni/Ce0.85Zr0.15O2 [54], 103.9 kJ/mol for 8.5Ni/CeO2 [55], 100.0 kJ/mol for 1Ni/CeO2 [56], and 120.3 kJ/mol for NiCe-0.01 [57]. Hence, it emphasizes the superior performance of Ni-Ce/CHE-SM which could be contributed by the synergistic effect of metals and support interaction. The previous catalytic performance results showed that both Ni-Ce/CHE-SM and Ni-La/CHE-SM catalysts clearly exhibited approximately 90 % CO2 conversion after reaching 350 °C. However, the rate of CH4 formation and apparent activation clearly illustrated that Ni-Ce/CHE-SM has a superior advantage in the activation of the reactants. Hence, both catalysts are subjected to FESEM and Raman analysis to investigate the changes in physicochemical properties after catalytic reaction. The FESEM images (Fig. S3) of both Ni-Ce/CHE-SM and Ni-La/CHE-SM catalysts illustrated the perseverance in maintaining the fibrous morphology after undergoes catalytic reaction at different temperature. This phenomenon further proves that incorporation of Ni and promoters within the CHE-SM framework would not resulting in the structure collapse due to the existence of rigid fibrous morphology. Meanwhile, Raman spectra in Fig. S4 exhibited the presence of graphitic and amorphous carbon for Ni-Ce/CHE-SM, located at 1610 and 1320 cm−1, respectively [58]. As for Ni-La/CHE-SM catalyst, there exist an insignificant amount for both types of carbon with a broad peak appeared that covered from 900 to 1200 cm−1 which attributed to the combination of C-C and C-H species [59,60]. The disparity in the Raman spectra for both catalysts might be from significant differences in rate of CH4 formation as shown in Fig. 7C where Ni-Ce/CHE-SM displayed the highest rate of CH4 formation from 250 to 350 °C. Therefore, an abundance of C- species would be presented on the surface of Ni-Ce/CHE-SM and contributed to the formation of amorphous and graphitic carbon. Taking this into account, the Ni-Ce/CHE-SM has been examined in stability test towards CO2 methanation for 50 h at 350 °C due to the highest rate of CH4 formation at this temperature for low-temperature region. The catalytic performance was displayed in Fig. S5 where Ni-Ce/CHE-SM exhibited a decreasing amount of ∼3 % in CO2 conversion after 50 h time on stream. This superior stability might be due to the existence of oxygen vacancies that could enhance the adsorption-desorption cycle of CO2 species along with carbon gasification which activates the deposited carbon, resulting in the participation of carbon species for further reaction. Besides, the CH4 selectivity for Ni-Ce/CHE-SM was sustained at 100 % during the 50 h stability test, further highlighting the ability of Ni-Ce/CHE-SM to resist CO formation from reverse water-gas shift reaction. 3.3 Effect of oxygen vacancy In addition, Ni-Ce/CHE-SM and Ni-La/CHE-SM are subjected to further investigation towards oxygen vacancy properties via XPS and Raman analysis. Prior to that, Fig. 8 illustrated the TEM images for fresh Ni-Ce/CHE-SM and Ni-La/CHE-SM where the fibrous structure of CHE-SM was preserved upon the addition of Ni metal and promoters. Moreover, the metal particle size of Ni-Ce/CHE-SM is much smaller than Ni-La/CHE-SM, suggesting high dispersion of Ni and Ce on the CHE-SM which align very well with the XRD and FESEM results (Figs. 1 and 3). The chemical states of Ni, O, Ce, and La were analyzed by the XPS analysis for Ni-Ce/CHE-SM and Ni-La/CHE-SM catalysts to unveil the effect of oxygen vacancy on catalytic performance. Fig. 9A illustrated the deconvoluted electronic state Ni 2p spectra of both catalysts where Ni 2p1/2 and 2p3/2 level peaks could be observed along with their corresponding satellite peaks [61–63]. Interestingly, all Ni 2p peaks for Ni-La/CHE-SM were located at higher binding energy compared to Ni-Ce/CHE-SM, suggesting higher charge transfer from nickel to lanthanum atoms. In addition, the intensity of Ni2p for Ni-Ce/CHE-SM is much higher than Ni-La/CHE-SM, suggesting that an abundance of NiO species was deposited on the surface of CHE-SM which explained the higher amount of metal reduction from H2-TPR result (Fig. 5 and Table S1). Fig. 9B revealed the deconvoluted O 1 s XPS spectra of Ni-Ce/CHE-SM and Ni-La/CHE-SM catalysts where two types of surface oxygen species can be observed. The peaks located approximately at 530 eV and 534 eV were assigned to lattice oxygen (OL) and oxygen vacancy (OV), respectively [64]. Generally, defective oxygen species (such as O2- and O−) are more reactive than lattice oxygen as they play a significant role in the dispersion of active metals, as a result after surface modification upon the incorporation of metals [65,66]. The ratio of OV:OL was calculated using their integrated areas and it showed that Ni-Ce/CHE-SM possessed a higher amount of oxygen vacancy compared to Ni-La/CHE-SM. This inference further supports the amount of CO2 desorption from Table S2 as Ni-Ce/CHE-SM exhibited strong basicity due to the presence of superoxide anions that were associated with oxygen vacancy. The Ce 3d spectra (Fig. 9C) of Ni-Ce/CHE-SM have been deconvoluted into α and β multiplets which correspond to the spin-orbit splitting of the 3d5/2 and 3d3/2 regions. Two peaks denoted as β (897.7 eV) and β’’ (903.0 eV) are designated to Ce3+ ions (3d104 f1 initial electronic state), while the remaining peaks denoted as α’’’’ (895.0 eV), β’ (900.3 eV), and β’’’ (914.1 eV) belong to Ce4+ ions (3d104 f0 initial electronic state) [67]. The existence of two oxidation states of Ce 3d in Ni-Ce/CHE-SM proved the formation of oxygen vacancy via the interaction of Ni metal with Ce species. Meanwhile, Fig. 9D shows the La 3d spectra of Ni-La/CHE-SM with two distinct peaks being observed. The peak located at 856.0 eV corresponds to La 3d5/2 while the peak at 862.2 eV was attributed to its satellite peak [68,69]. Obviously, the La atoms of Ni-La/CHE-SM existed in a single oxidation state only which is La3+. This phenomenon explained the reason behind the large difference in the amount of oxygen vacancy as there is no charge transfer perceived in the La oxidation state. Fig. 10A displays the Raman spectra of Ni-Ce/CHE-SM and Ni-La/CHE-SM for acquiring additional information regarding the structure and defects of both catalysts. Both catalysts exhibited an apparent broad peak ranging from 300 to 700 cm−1 which was deconvoluted into four distinguished peaks. These peaks are denoted as D4, R, D1, and D2 correspond to the bending of five or more silicate member rings, the bending of Si-O-Si bridges, four silicate member rings, and three silicate member rings, respectively [65,70,71]. The D4 and R peaks indicate the structure of silica within the CHE-SM catalyst along with the small peak located around 230 cm−1 which correlated with scissoring in [SiO4/2] tetrahedron [71]. Fig. 10B displays that Ni-Ce/CHE-SM acquires a higher amount of D4 and R peaks compared to Ni-La/CHE-SM, suggesting that the silica structure was preserved within Ni-Ce/CHE-SM after incorporating Ni and Ce. Generally, oxygen vacancies are generated in order to maintain overall charge neutrality within the catalyst system. In this study, the D1 and D2 peaks located at ∼500–700 cm−1 are assigned with defects-induced bands in the silica framework with the ability to generate oxygen vacancies [72–74]. These silicate member rings could form oxygen vacancies by the removal of oxygen atoms from the Si-O-Si bridge, thus resulting in the Si-Si formation. Gao et al. have stated in their studies that the formation of oxygen vacancies is more favorable in the silicate rings rather than in silica chains [75]. Thus, the higher amount of defect bands in the Ni-Ce/CHE-SM has contributed to a greater amount of oxygen vacancies. In addition, these silicate member rings might have been isomorphously substituted by Ce ions which enhance the formation of oxygen vacancies. The proposed structure of these phenomena has been illustrated in Fig. 11. Meanwhile, Humbert et al. described that the Si-OH species gave rise to the formation of three silicate member rings (D2) through the condensation process [72]. It is evident from FTIR-KBr results (Fig. 4) that Ni-Ce/CHE-SM possessed lower amounts of external Si-OH species compared to Ni-La/CHE-SM which in turn gave rise to higher amounts of D2 peak. Meanwhile, Khatun et al. associated peaks at ∼560 cm−1 and 630 cm−1 with extrinsic defects (De) and intrinsic defects (Di), respectively, through Raman analysis on NP/CeO2 [65]. They asserted that De came from Ce4+ which was replaced by Ni2+/Pt2+ while Di originated when the reduction of Ce4+ to Ce3+ occurred. Therefore, it is postulated that both D1 and D2 peaks might be referring to the isomorphously substituted Si atoms with Ce and La promoters where they generate the oxygen vacancies via extrinsic and intrinsic routes. The total amount of oxygen vacancy corresponds to the sum of D1 and D2 peak areas where Ni-Ce/CHE-SM possessed the highest amount of oxygen vacancies which aligns with the XPS result. 4 Conclusion In summary, a microemulsion technique was used to prepare CHE-SM, and the incorporation of 5 wt% promoters (Ce, La, Mo, and Zr) and 20 wt% Ni into CHE-SM was synthesized using one pot impregnation method. In this study, Ni-Ce/CHE-SM displayed excellent catalytic performance towards CO2 methanation with CO2 conversion reached 80 % at 250 °C, emphasizing its capabilities in activating the reaction at low temperatures. Meanwhile, Ni-La/CHE-SM only achieved 70 % CO2 conversion at this temperature followed by Ni-Mo/CHE-SM (20 % CO2 conversion) and Ni-Zr/CHE-SM (15 % CO2 conversion). The extraordinary catalytic performance of Ni-Ce/CHE-SM was owing to the abundance of oxygen vacancies within its framework as proved by the XPS result. The addition of Ce promoter also enhanced the dispersion of NiO with a crystallite size of 2.49 nm as shown by XRD analysis. In addition, FTIR-KBr result showed a large amount of ion exchange and ismorphous substitution occurred within the Ni-Ce/CHE-SM forming Si-O-Ni and Si-O-Ce. The Raman analysis illustrated the defects structure of CHE-SM which are three and four silicate member rings. It is expected that the Si atom was substituted with the Ce atom which resulted in the formation of more oxygen vacancies. These phenomena further improve the medium and strong basicity of Ni-Ce/CHE-SM. Hence, additional active sites will be provided to adsorb CO2 and H2 reactants which result in higher CH4 production with low activation energy. CRediT authorship contribution statement N.S. coredata.dc:description: A series of promoters (Ce, La, Mo, and Zr) was introduced into the Ni/CHE-SM catalyst by using the impregnation method and tested for CO2 methanation. Among these, Ni-Ce/CHE-SM possessed a high CO2 conversion of 80 % at 250 °C, signifying its potential at low temperature. The superior performance of Ni-Ce/CHE-SM was attributed to the formation of Si-O-Ni and Si-O-Ce species, as confirmed by FTIR-KBr analysis. XPS and CO2-TPD analyses revealed an abundance of oxygen vacancies existed within Ni-Ce/CHE-SM, resulting in enhancement of basicity amount and strength. In addition, Raman analysis showed the existence of three and four silica member rings which was believed that the Si atom be substituted with the Ce atom, thus contributing to create more oxygen vacancies. Hence, additional active sites were provided which enhance the adsorption of reactant molecules and improve the production of CH4, thus emphasizing the greater potential of Ni-Ce/CHE-SM in CO2 methanation application.
